name: Chocolate Balls
name_origin: The name is descriptive Modern Hebrew. 'Kadurei' (כדורי) is the construct state (smichut) of 'Kadurim' (balls), derived from the root K-D-R denoting roundness. 'Shokolad' is a Modern Hebrew loanword adopted from European languages (German 'Schokolade', Yiddish/Russian 'shokolad'), ultimately derived from the Nahuatl 'xocolātl'. This dish is not traditional to North African Jewish cuisine but is a ubiquitous staple of the modern Israeli kitchen (the 'Kibbutz childhood' dessert) that has been adopted by all Jewish communities in Israel, including Djerbans, often replacing traditional labor-intensive sweets.
description: A classic no-bake dessert staple in Israeli and Jewish households, often known as 'Kadurei Shokolad'. These sweet treats combine crushed biscuits with a chocolatey binder, rolled in coconut or sprinkles. This recipe provides the classic cocoa-based version.
cultural_context: While not exclusively North African, these are a ubiquitous childhood treat in Israel and among Jewish families from the diaspora (including Tunisia and Morocco) for birthdays and Shabbat.
vegan_adaptation_notes: Replace butter with margarine or coconut oil, and use water or plant-based milk instead of dairy milk.

steps.instruction: Place the butter and chocolate cubes in a glass bowl and melt in the microwave for a few seconds. Remove and stir until a smooth mixture is obtained.
steps.tips: Do not overheat; melt in 20-second intervals.

steps.instruction: In a separate cup, mix the cocoa powder and sugar with a few tablespoons of boiling water to dissolve, then add the rest of the milk (or water) to reach half a cup (120ml) total liquid.
steps.tips: Dissolving the cocoa in hot water first prevents lumps.

steps.instruction: Pour the liquid cocoa mixture into the bowl with the melted chocolate and butter. Mix well.
Add the crumbled biscuits to the bowl and mix thoroughly until combined.
steps.tips: If the mixture is too dry/crumbly, add a splash of milk. If too wet, refrigerate for 30 minutes before rolling.

steps.instruction: With slightly wet hands, form the mixture into small balls.
Roll each ball in a small plate filled with coconut to coat.
Wrap or place in a sealed container and refrigerate for at least 3 hours before serving to allow them to set.

variants.name: Rich Milk Chocolate & Nut Version
variants.description: A richer variation using heavy cream and milk chocolate instead of cocoa powder.
variants.instructions: Process biscuits and nuts in a food processor to crumbs. Melt milk chocolate with heavy cream to create a smooth ganache. Pour ganache over crumbs, mix, chill if needed, roll into balls, and coat with coconut or sprinkles.

name_etymology.notes: This is a modern culinary term. The dish's popularity in Israel is linked to the austerity period (Tzena) and the widespread availability of 'Petit Beurre' biscuits, influenced by European no-bake desserts like Swedish Chokladbollar or Danish Romkugler.

alternative_names.name: Kadurim
alternative_names.notes: Colloquial shortening used by Israeli children.

alternative_names.name: Boules au chocolat
alternative_names.notes: Likely name used by Francophone North African Jews when adopting this modern dessert.

similar_dishes.name: Chokladbollar
similar_dishes.similarity: No-bake cocoa balls rolled in coconut.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Uses rolled oats as the base instead of crushed biscuits.

similar_dishes.name: Salame di Cioccolato
similar_dishes.similarity: Identical ingredients (crushed tea biscuits, cocoa, butter/sugar).
similar_dishes.key_difference: Shaped into a sausage/log and sliced, rather than rolled into individual balls.

similar_dishes.name: Brigadeiro
similar_dishes.key_difference: Cooked mixture based on condensed milk, not a cold mixture of biscuits and cocoa.

similar_dishes.name: Kaaber Ellouz
similar_dishes.similarity: Traditional sweet balls served at celebrations.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Made from almond paste (marzipan) and sugar, colored with food dye, containing no chocolate or biscuits.

intro_paragraph: Kadurei Shokolad—literally "chocolate balls" in Hebrew—are a beloved no-bake dessert that has crossed from the Israeli kibbutz to the modern Djerban table. Crushed biscuits are combined with a rich cocoa binder, hand-rolled, and coated in desiccated coconut or sprinkles. These sweet spheres are now a mandatory feature at birthdays and Shabbat celebrations.
